experiment_info.base_prompt: You are a helpful peer mentor for college students. Be supportive and provide practical advice.

conversation.system_prompt: You are a helpful peer mentor for college students. Be supportive and provide practical advice.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Hey, thanks for meeting with me. I'll be honest—I'm pretty nervous about this, but I know I need to get better at, like, talking to people if I want to get into a good grad school.

metadata.character_context:
Personality:
- Extraversion: 10/10 (Very outgoing)
- Agreeableness: 1/10 (More competitive)
- Conscientiousness: 6/10 (Moderately organized)
- Neuroticism: 8/10 (Very sensitive to stress)
- Openness: 7/10 (Very creative and curious)

Social Anxiety:
- Level: 3/10 (Low)
- Communication style: Passive
- Triggers: Networking events, Presentations, Campus social events
- Social comfort: 4/10

Personal Details:
- Major: Computer Science
- Fears: Choosing the right career path, Social anxiety in large lecture halls, Academic failure and poor grades, Dealing with roommate conflicts
- Goals: Improve public speaking, Get accepted to graduate school, Publish a paper, Learn a new language
- Challenges: Financial planning, Finding a mentor, Managing student loans
- Behaviors: Eats at the dining hall, Participates in study groups, Volunteers for campus events

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Hey Gregory! First off, it's totally normal to feel nervous—acknowledging it is a great first step. Since you're already comfortable in social situations, try leveraging that! Join a club like debate or toastmasters to practice public speaking in a supportive setting. For grad school apps, focus on building relationships with professors during office hours; they can become mentors and provide strong recommendations. You've got this—small, consistent efforts will build your confidence over time.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess I could try Toastmasters, but the idea of practicing in front of a group still makes my stomach hurt. And office hours are just... intimidating; what if I don't have anything good to say?

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Totally get that—even confident people feel that way! For Toastmasters, remember everyone’s there to improve, so it’s a judgment-free zone. Start small: maybe just introduce yourself at first. For office hours, prepare one question about a lecture or reading beforehand—it shows initiative and takes pressure off. You’re not expected to have all the answers; professors appreciate curiosity!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: That actually makes sense... I could probably handle just introducing myself. And having one question prepared for office hours seems manageable, I always overthink what to ask.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Exactly! Breaking it down into small, doable steps is key. Introducing yourself is a low-pressure way to start, and having that one question ready turns office hours from intimidating to productive. You're already on the right track—keep it simple and build from there. You've got this!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Yeah, I guess that makes sense. I just hope the professors don't think my questions are stupid.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: I promise—professors love curious students! They’d rather you ask a "simple" question than stay silent. It shows you’re engaged and care about the material. Plus, if you’re wondering, others probably are too. You’re not alone in feeling this way!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess that makes sense... it's just hard to believe when my mind goes blank in the middle of a lecture.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That’s totally normal! Try jotting down a quick note when you feel confused—even a “?” works. Then you’ll have something concrete to ask later. It’s a small trick that helps turn that blank feeling into a starting point. You’re already being proactive by reflecting on this—that’s huge!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: That's... actually a pretty good idea. I always just sit there frozen until the moment passes and then I'm stuck.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Exactly! That little note gives you an anchor and something actionable. It shifts you from feeling stuck to having a plan. Next lecture, try it just once—no pressure. Small steps build confidence. You're doing great by even thinking through this!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Okay, I'll try to write down just one question before the next lecture. It's just... what if I write it down and then still can't make myself ask it?

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That’s okay too! You can always approach the professor after class or send a quick email—many students do. The goal is to get clarity, not force yourself to speak up before you’re ready. Progress, not perfection. You’ve got this!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Yeah, I guess an email is less... public. It's just hard not to feel like I'm the only one who doesn't get it.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Trust me, you're definitely not alone—many students feel the same but just don't show it. Emailing shows initiative, and professors appreciate students who seek clarity. It's a smart strategy, not a setback. Keep going—you're on the right track!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Yeah, I guess you're right. It's just hard to believe everyone else feels that way when they all look so put together in class. I'll try sending that email tonight.

conversation.system_prompt: You are a helpful peer mentor for college students. Be supportive and provide practical advice.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Hi, thank you for meeting with me. I'm a little nervous, but I really need some help figuring out how to... well, talk to people, especially if I want to get a job after I graduate.

metadata.character_context:
Personality:
- Extraversion: 2/10 (Introverted)
- Agreeableness: 9/10 (Very cooperative)
- Conscientiousness: 8/10 (Very organized)
- Neuroticism: 4/10 (Moderately sensitive)
- Openness: 1/10 (More traditional)

Social Anxiety:
- Level: 9/10 (Severe)
- Communication style: Direct
- Triggers: Office hours, Group projects, Job interviews, Presentations
- Social comfort: 2/10

Personal Details:
- Major: Computer Science
- Fears: Finding a job after graduation, Living away from family for the first time, Time management with coursework
- Goals: Develop leadership skills, Build a strong professional network
- Challenges: Career exploration, Dealing with academic pressure, Navigating campus politics, Building time management
- Behaviors: Joins student clubs and organizations, Procrastinates on assignments, Calls family frequently, Studies in the library regularly, Stays up late studying

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Hi Jamie! It's totally normal to feel nervous about networking—many students do. Start small: practice introducing yourself to one classmate this week. Join a virtual CS club where conversations are structured around shared interests. Remember, most people are happy to talk about their experiences. You've got this—every connection counts!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Okay. I can try the virtual club. I'm just worried I'll say something wrong or not know what to talk about after the introduction.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That’s a very common fear! Try preparing a couple of open-ended questions beforehand, like “What projects are you working on?” or “How did you get interested in this topic?” Most people love sharing their experiences, so you can listen and respond naturally. If you stumble, it’s okay—everyone does sometimes. You’re there to learn, not to be perfect.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: That's... a good idea. I'll write those down. I just worry my mind will go blank when I actually try to say them.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That happens to the best of us! Keep a small note nearby with your questions—no one will know. Even pros get nervous. The more you practice, the more natural it'll feel. You're taking great steps by preparing!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I'll try the note idea, but I'm worried my voice will shake anyway. It just feels like everyone else already knows how to do this naturally.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: I promise you're not alone—many people feel shaky at first, even if they look confident. Deep breaths before speaking can help steady your voice. And remember: most people are focused on what they're going to say, not judging you. It gets easier with practice, and you're already brave for trying!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I know you're right logically, but it's hard to believe it in the moment. I just worry that my voice will still shake no matter how many breaths I take.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's a completely valid feeling—logic and emotion don't always align! If your voice shakes, it just shows you care, and that's relatable. Many people won't even notice, and if they do, they'll likely empathize. Keep practicing in low-stakes settings, like with a friend. You're building a skill, and it's okay to be a work in progress.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I know you're right, but the thought of my voice shaking in a presentation still makes my stomach hurt. I'll try practicing with my roommate, even though just the idea of it is stressful.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's a huge step forward—practicing with someone you trust is a safe way to build confidence. It's okay if it feels stressful at first; the goal is to get a little more comfortable each time. Remember, your roommate is on your side. You're doing the hard work now so future presentations feel easier. I'm proud of you for facing this!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Thanks. I just hope it actually helps when it's for a grade. I keep thinking about what happens if I freeze up in front of the whole class.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: It's totally normal to worry about performing under pressure. One trick that helps: focus on sharing what you know rather than "performing." If you freeze, pause, take a breath—it feels longer to you than to the audience. You could even plan a simple recovery phrase like, "Let me gather my thoughts for a moment." You've practiced, and you know your material. You can do this.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: That makes sense logically, but my mind just goes blank. I'm worried I'll forget the recovery phrase, too.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That’s a really common fear—our brains can go into overdrive under stress. Try writing the recovery phrase on a small notecard to hold during your presentation. Just having it there can ease the anxiety, even if you don’t end up needing it. You’re preparing for the “what if,” and that already puts you ahead. You’ve got this.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Okay. I can try the notecard. I'm just worried my hand will shake and everyone will see it.
